SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Getting the right amount of exercise can rev up your energy levels and even help improve your mood.”
What does the phrase “rev up” mean in the sentence?

A.Choice: protect

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by information in the passage.

B.Choice: accept

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by information in the passage.

C.Choice: increase

Key.Rationale: The phrase “rev up” implies that energy levels can increase with the right amount of exercise.

D.Choice: reverse

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by information in the passage.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“This may not seem important now, but your body will thank you later.”
What does the figurative language in the sentence suggest?

A.Choice: Exercise has long-term effects on the body.

Key.Rationale: The passage provides several examples of how exercise can have long-term positive effects on the body.

B.Choice: Exercise requirements change as the body ages.

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the context of the provided sentence.

C.Choice: Exercise should be pain free for the body from the beginning.

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the context of the provided sentence.

D.Choice: Exercise methods should be chosen carefully to protect the body.

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the context of the provided sentence.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.

:box:“When you give your heart this kind of workout regularly, it will get stronger and more e͟f͟f͟i͟c͟i͟e͟n͟t in delivering oxygen (in the form of oxygen-carrying blood cells) to all parts of your body.”
What does the word e͟f͟f͟i͟c͟i͟e͟n͟t mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: capable

Key.Rationale: “Capable” fits the context of the sentence.

B.Choice: obvious

Key.Rationale: This option is an incorrect meanings of the word “efficient” and does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

C.Choice: necessary

Key.Rationale: This option is an incorrect meanings of the word “efficient” and does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

D.Choice: original

Key.Rationale: This option is an incorrect meanings of the word “efficient” and does not make sense in the context of the sentence.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not (e.g., fact/opinion, bias).
Content: Which evidence from the passage best supports the generalization that “activities that encourage flexibility are easy to find”?

A.Choice: “When picking the right type of exercise, it can help to consider your workout personality.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on finding an exercise program that is the right fit for maintaining a healthy weight.

B.Choice: “It's a good idea to talk to someone who understands the exercise ...”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on finding an exercise program that is the right fit for maintaining a healthy weight.

C.Choice: “This is especially true for teens, who are still growing.”

Key.Rationale: This option focuses on finding an exercise program that is the right fit for maintaining a healthy weight.

D.Choice: “Even small things can count as exercise when you're starting out ...”

Key.Rationale: The passage discusses how ballet, gymnastics, and yoga can help keep a person healthy and explains the importance of stretching after working out. Both details are evidence that help support the generalization that “activities that encourage flexibility are easy to find.”

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences and/or generalizations drawn from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage best explains why teens may want to consider solo sports instead of team sports?

A.Choice: “In fact, exercise is one of the most important parts of keeping your body healthy.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not explain why a solo sport should be considered.

B.Choice: “In fact, the types of exercise that you do on your own are easier to continue when you leave high school and go on to work or college ...”

Key.Rationale: This option gives reasons why teens may want to consider solo sports.

C.Choice: “When you use your muscles and they become stronger, you can be active for longer periods of time without getting worn out.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not explain why a solo sport should be considered.

D.Choice: “One of the biggest reasons people drop an exercise program is lack of interest.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not explain why a solo sport should be considered.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, section, or text feature fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: Why are headings included in the passage?

A.Choice: to define key terms in each section

Key.Rationale: This option does not accurately describe the purpose of the headings.

B.Choice: to offer a possible solution to a problem

Key.Rationale: This option does not accurately describe the purpose of the headings.

C.Choice: to answer questions from the author

Key.Rationale: This option does not accurately describe the purpose of the headings.

D.Choice: to identify the topic of each section

Key.Rationale: The headings identify the topic of each section.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences and/or generalizations drawn from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What generalization can be made based on the information in the section “Too Much of a Good Thing”?

A.Choice: Athletes should limit the time spent on one sport.

Key.Rationale: The detail “exercising too much to lose weight isn't healthy” supports the idea that athletes should limit the amount of time spent on a sport.

B.Choice: There is a sport or activity to fit every workout style.

Key.Rationale: This generalization is not supported in the section “Too Much of a Good Thing.”

C.Choice: Being flexible can improve how well one performs a sport.

Key.Rationale: This generalization is not supported in the section “Too Much of a Good Thing.

D.Choice: Playing several sports will strengthen a variety of muscles.

Key.Rationale: This generalization is not supported in the section “Too Much of a Good Thing.

Content: Which sentence from the passage best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “And, if you have an injury, make sure you give yourself enough time to heal.”

Key.Rationale: This does not relate to the correct generalization in Part One.

B.Choice: “The body needs enough calories to function properly.”

Key.Rationale: This does not relate to the correct generalization in Part One.

C.Choice: “It's also possible to overtrain—something athletes need to watch out for.”

Key.Rationale: The word “overtrain” supports the idea that only a certain amount of time should be spent on a sport.

D.Choice: “Also, never exercise through pain.”

Key.Rationale: This does not relate to the correct generalization in Part One.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, or elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples, anecdotes, or sequence of steps).
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Based on information in the passage, what is the main difference between aerobic exercise and strength training?

A.Choice: the age of the person each benefits

Key.Rationale: The passage does not identify the appropriate age for each type of exercise.

B.Choice: the amount of money each costs

Key.Rationale: The cost of exercise is not discussed.

C.Choice: the amount of practice each requires

Key.Rationale: The amount of time to practice each type of exercise is not provided.

D.Choice: the muscles of the body each targets

Key.Rationale: Te details “the heart enjoys a good workout” and “different types of exercise strengthen different muscle groups” are details that support the idea that different muscles benefit from these types of exercises.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “Like other muscles, the heart enjoys a good workout.”

Key.Rationale: This option options identifies the types of muscles that benefit from a specific type of exercise.

B.Choice: “Being flexible may also help improve a person's sports performance.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not describe the muscles that are targeted by a specific type of exercise.

C.Choice: “Those gym class standbys are also good for building arm muscles.”

Key.Rationale: This option options identifies the types of muscles that benefit from a specific type of exercise.

D.Choice: “If so, solo sports like biking or snowboarding may be for you.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not describe the muscles that are targeted by a specific type of exercise.

Topics: Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Out of the south the biplane came winging back toward the camp, a black speck against the dazzling white of the vast ice fields that extended unbroken to the horizon on every side.”
How does the sentence contribute to the passage?

A.Choice: It gives the reader clues as to the overall theme of the story.

Key.Rationale: The sentence itself does not provide clues to the overall theme of the passage.

B.Choice: It explains why the men in the plane are coming back to camp.

Key.Rationale: The sentence does not explain why the men are coming back.

C.Choice: It gives the reader a visual image of where the story takes place.

Key.Rationale: “Vast ice fields that extended unbroken to the horizon on every side” provides an image to indicate where the story takes place.

D.Choice: It hints at the problems that the main character will have later in the story.

Key.Rationale: The given sentence does not foreshadow problems the main character will have.

Topics: Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“ 'But Jim Dodd and I picked up something, and Jim seems to have gone crazy.' ”
How does the sentence help to develop the plot?

A.Choice: It shows that Jim and Tommy already have different viewpoints of the same situation.

Key.Rationale: The given sentence indicates that Tommy has a different viewpoint than Jim does.

B.Choice: It shows that Jim and Tommy are good friends who have known each other for a while.

Key.Rationale: This answer cannot be concluded from the details in the sentence.

C.Choice: It suggests that Jim and Tommy will continue to go on expeditions together in the plane.

Key.Rationale: This answer cannot be concluded from the details in the sentence.

D.Choice: It suggests that Jim and Tommy are soon to go on a dangerous adventure.

Key.Rationale: This answer cannot be concluded from the details in the sentence.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word m͟a͟n͟e͟u͟v͟e͟r͟i͟n͟g mean as it is used in the passage?

A.Choice: marking

Key.Rationale: This is an incorrect meaning of the word “maneuvering” and does not make sense in the context used in the passage.

B.Choice: moving

Key.Rationale: “Maneuvering” means changing positions or moving.

C.Choice: mistaking

Key.Rationale: This is an incorrect meaning of the word “maneuvering” and does not make sense in the context used in the passage.

D.Choice: monitoring

Key.Rationale: This is an incorrect meaning of the word “maneuvering” and does not make sense in the context used in the passage.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Based on the prefix “im-,” what does “impartial” mean?

A.Choice: not taking sides

Key.Rationale: Since the prefix “im-” means “not,” the word “impartial” means “not taking sides.”

B.Choice: taking opposite sides

Key.Rationale: This option does not reflect the correct meanings of the prefix “im-.”

C.Choice: taking sides again

Key.Rationale: This option does not reflect the correct meanings of the prefix “im-.”

D.Choice: the act of taking sides

Key.Rationale: This option does not reflect the correct meanings of the prefix “im-.”

Topics: Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“ 'So let's drop the argument and remember that we've got to pull together!' ”
How does the author use the phrase “to pull together”?

A.Choice: to illustrate Captain Storm's desire to have a group of friends

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by details from the passage.

B.Choice: to suggest that Captain Storm likes to debate with others

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by details from the passage.

C.Choice: to show that Captain Storm enjoys being a sailor on the expedition

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by details from the passage.

D.Choice: to show Captain Storm's belief in working for the same cause

Key.Rationale: “To pull together” suggests people uniting to work for the same cause.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Warm fog that was like balm upon his frozen skin, but of a warmth that was impossible within a few miles of the frozen pole.”
What does the simile “warm fog that was like balm upon his frozen skin” suggest?

A.Choice: The fog gave Tommy a reason to feel afraid of the future.

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by the context.

B.Choice: The fog felt very cold to Tommy.

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by the context.

C.Choice: The fog felt very comforting to Tommy.

Key.Rationale: “Balm” indicates something that soothes the skin.

D.Choice: The fog hinted to Tommy that he was going to crash the plane.

Key.Rationale: This idea is not supported by the context.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences and/or generalizations drawn from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
Which word describes how Jim Dodd felt when he discovered the fossil?

A.Choice: sympathetic

Key.Rationale: This feeling is not supported by details in the passage.

B.Choice: doubtful

Key.Rationale: This feeling is not supported by details in the passage.

C.Choice: delighted

Key.Rationale: Details in the passage support the idea that Jim Dodd is delighted about discovering the fossil beetles.

D.Choice: frustrated

Key.Rationale: This feeling is not supported by details in the passage.

Content: Which sentence from the passage best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “It resembled nothing so much as an enormous beetle.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the correct inference in Part One.

B.Choice: “This substance, which was fully three inches thick over the thorax, looked as hard as plate armor.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the correct inference in Part One.

C.Choice: “ 'A beetle, but with the shell of a crustacean instead of mere chitin.' ”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the correct inference in Part One.

D.Choice: “ 'We'll drop everything else, and spend years, if need be, looking for other specimens.' ”

Key.Rationale: Drop everything else” and “spend years” support the idea that Jim Dodd is delighted when the fossil is found.

SubTopics: Describe how the plot of a particular story, drama, or poem unfolds, as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
At what point during the storm does Tommy first realize that things at the South Pole are not as he expects them to be?

A.Choice: when he sees a snowstorm that blackens the sky

Key.Rationale: The snowstorm occurs before the rain.

B.Choice: when he sees a shrimp that is of an enormous size

Key.Rationale: This event occurs after the weather becomes warmer.

C.Choice: when the plane starts going in circles

Key.Rationale: This event occurs after the weather becomes warmer.

D.Choice: when the weather becomes warmer

Key.Rationale: Tommy begins to wonder if he is dreaming when the snow turns to rain and the fog is seen, both indications that the weather has become warmer.

Content: Which sentences support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “The plane was no longer controllable.”

Key.Rationale: This option is the snowstorm that causes the plane to become uncontrollable.

B.Choice: The snow was no longer snow, but rain ...”

Key.Rationale: This option provides details that support the correct answer in Part One.

C.Choice: “Fog like white wool, drifting past him in fleecy flakes that looked as if they had solid substance.”

Key.Rationale: This option provides details that support the correct answer in Part One.

D.Choice: “A grayish body, half-covered with grains of sand emerged, waving two enormously long tentacles.”

Key.Rationale: The grayish body is seen after the weather becomes warmer.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In the passage “Two Amazing Tales of Memory,” the concept of memory is discussed. Write an essay analyzing the effect that Mr. S's memory had on his life. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Produce complete sentences, recognizing and correcting inappropriate fragments and run-on sentences.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Jamie collected stones for a wall he wanted to build carefully he put each one into place. (2) He wanted the wall to look as if it had been there for many years without any changes. (3) He had carefully selected stones to make the new wall look just as old as the other nearby walls did. (4) Jamie stood back and admired the work that he had already accomplished.
Which sentence is a run-on and should be written as two sentences?

A.Choice: sentence 1

Key.Rationale: This optino contains two sentences written as one sentence and is therefore a run-on sentence (“Jamie collected stones for a wall he wanted to build” and “carefully he put each one into place”).

B.Choice: sentence 2

Key.Rationale: This option is a grammatically correct complex sentences.

C.Choice: sentence 3

Key.Rationale: This option is a grammatically correct complex sentences.

D.Choice: sentence 4

Key.Rationale: This option is a grammatically correct complex sentences.

SubTopics: Use punctuation to separate items in a series.
Content: Which sentence needs an additional comma?

A.Choice: Please check to see that the newspaper has the correct month, the correct day, and the correct year.

Key.Rationale: This option correctly uses commas to separate items in a series.

B.Choice: My friends and I talked about what we would write about for our project, what resources we would use, and where we would find the information.

Key.Rationale: This option correctly uses commas to separate items in a series.

C.Choice: Do you plan to read a book, watch a play at the community center, or walk to the park?

Key.Rationale: This option correctly uses commas to separate items in a series.

D.Choice: Are you planning to walk, ride your bicycle take the bus, or get a ride to the library?

Key.Rationale: This option is missing a comma to separate items in a series (“ride your bicycle” and “take the bus”).

SubTopics: Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from a newspaper article.
:box:The seventh-grade basketball team lost the district championship game at the last second.
Which sentence could be added to best fit the style of this sentence?

A.Choice: The players felt down in the dumps afterward.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the style of the sentence from the newspaper article.

B.Choice: Later on, the kids were all totally unhappy.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the style of the sentence from the newspaper article.

C.Choice: The team members were greatly disappointed.

Key.Rationale: This option uses diction that is consistent with the style of the sentence from a newspaper article (“greatly disappointed”).

D.Choice: After that, the guys were completely crushed.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the style of the sentence from the newspaper article.

SubTopics: Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Content: Read the paragraph.
:box:The carrier crab is an interesting sea creature. Its back legs are designed to help it carry large objects. The crab uses these objects to defend itself.
Which sentence could be added to best fit the style of the paragraph?

A.Choice: It's awfully rare to see a carrier crab.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the paragraph.

B.Choice: Carrier crabs carry seaweed and other stuff.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the paragraph.

C.Choice: This behavior is not common among sea creatures.

Key.Rationale: This option presents diction that is consistent with the style of the paragraph.

D.Choice: Scientists aren't totally sure how many of these crabs exist.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces diction that is inconsistent with the paragraph.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective techniques, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.
Content:
:box:Think about writing a story with the title “An Unforgettable Adventure.” Consider what happened before, during, and after the adventure.

For your teacher, write a story with the title “An Unforgettable Adventure.” Consider story elements (for example, character, setting, and plot) as you develop your narrative.
